POR.DRECONTENT:
Representation theory is a field of mathematics, encapsulating the study of symmetry, and many elaborations upon this theme. Some of the most important objects of study are Coxeter groups, which are collections of symmetries that come from reflections (like looking at oneself through a mirror, or through a sequence of mirrors positioned at different angles). Weyl groups are a special class of Coxeter groups that play a major role in physics and crystallography. Fundamental work of the late 20th century demonstrated that the representation theory of Weyl groups can be extracted from certain geometric objects called flag varieties (which are complicated, higher-dimensional structures). Aside from the intrinsic interest that arises when disparate fields (representation theory and geometry) are united, connections like these also allow powerful tools to be transferred from one arena to another. For example, the Kazhdan-Lusztig conjecture tries to compute certain numbers called multiplicities in representation theory, which encode how "big" certain objects are. It was proven for Weyl groups using the decomposition theorem, a technical theorem in geometry. General Coxeter groups do not admit an analogous geometric setting, which is why much less was known about them.

Ultimately, however, this geometric setup is difficult and highly technical. For this reason, geometric representation theory is one of the most imposing, inaccessible fields in mathematics. In the 1990s, Soergel provided a method which reduced many questions about flag varieties to questions about objects now known as Soergel bimodules. These are algebraic in nature, and thus are more accessible to elementary techniques. They also encode the representation theory of all Coxeter groups, not just Weyl groups.

The Kazhdan-Lusztig conjecture was rephrased by Soergel as the Soergel conjecture, which asks how "big" the Soergel bimodules are. This problem (now for general Coxeter groups) was solved by Ben Elias (the PI) and Geordie Williamson during this grant. The crucial method was to adapt the decomposition theorem, finding algebraic analogs of this geometric tool and its geometric proof. There are many other areas of mathematics where simpler, algebraic analogs are being found for geometric constructions, and one hopes that more results can be proven along the same lines.

Another major goal, also accomplished by Elias and Williamson during this grant, was to follow in Soergel's footsteps and simply the theory yet further.  We have now produced Soergel diagrams, which are special pictures drawn on a plane (e.g. a sheet of paper), and have reduced many algebraic questions (which involve manipulating polynomials) to graphical ones (which involve manipulating pictures). For the first time, computations can be done easily by hand and quickly by computer. These computations allowed Geordie Williamson to disprove the long-standing "Lusztig Conjecture," which had motivated the field for some time. Soergel diagrams also allowed Elias to give a simple, pictorial proof of the geometric Satake equivalence, an extremely complex result linking geometry and representation theory.

This transformation has allowed mathematicians at all levels entrance to an otherwise mysterious area. During the grant, Elias mentored several projects in this field for undergraduates and gifted high schoolers, under the auspices of various research programs at MIT (including the PRIMES-USA program, for which he served as a program coordinator). Elias also ran several intensive workshops, in Denmark, India, and Oregon, where he introduced young graduate students to Soergel bimodules.
